item.title: 498 - Strange Strings
item.dc:creator: @Discount_Waffles Discount Waffles
item.description:
@Discount_Waffles wrote:

http://pastebin.ca/1043115

This is from 474 … I haven’t touched it in quite a while so it may be a little outdated.
Cache 12 has all of the “clientscripts” and what not…
I had made a very, very primitive “conversion” class that did something like this:

[ 0]: PUSH 5 TO INTSTACK
3305 0
4106 0
[ 3]: PUSH " / " TO STRINGSTACK
[ 0]: PUSH 5 TO INTSTACK
3306 0
4106 0
[37]: APPEND LAST 3 STRINGS, PUSH TO STRINGSTACK ["#1"]
[33]: PUSH intParams[0] TO INTSTACK
2112 0
[21]: RETURN

-----------
getComponent(v0).setText(intToString(currentSkillLevel[5]) +  " / "  + intToString(maxSkillLevel[5]))
return {}

Read full topic

item.title: 498 - Strange Strings
item.dc:creator: @ruler ruler
item.description:
@ruler wrote:

[quote=“semaphore, post:34, topic:206697”]You are sincerely stupid ruler.

  1. amazing feat… had nothing to do with jagex… I was referencing the fact that you are dumber than I had originally thought… which was an amazing feat - you moron
  2. ‘largest codebase changes since" - more like the only’ - Actually if you had the historical builds, you would have seen that I was right on that account as well. They had made more than a couple changes to the codebase. But since you are a complete blithering idiot, you would not have seen that.

And finally for your completely and total failure. You continually mention that I had warned people that they were watching mouse packets. It was absolutely true. They turned the flag on for everyone. And you… are still too dense to realize/admit that I was right. nice /fail

As for my history? Yes I have a history of telling things as they are.

@Mopman: You’re right, I cannot give too much information but what I can say is fairly public knowledge. There are over 300 different permutations of the warden at any given time. The warden is polymorphic… meaning there can be over 300 different permutations of the warden all of which are functionally identical. The warden itself can be swapped out many times during a client’s connection. Every 15 seconds the server initiates one of the dozen or so scans available to the warden. The warden handles it and responds typically with a yes/no type response. Very rarely is the response anything more. The connection I was making between the two is that using their cache, jagex can implement something very similar. The codebase wouldn’t have to change, the cache could change and even more they could have it change while the character is playing. This change could implement a new script; runnable in their vm. I didn’t mean to imply that the warden is necessarily scriptable. What I meant to imply that the same cloaking/detection could be implemented using this vm. The strength of the warden is that for a short time upon warden update, the cheater is prone/vulnerable to the scans until the scan becomes cracked/broken and the cheater is protected again. Jagex could do the same thing. For the short time/or long time that they introduce a new script the cheater could be vulnerable. It all depends on how far they want to take this.[/quote]
http://onwarden.blogspot.com/

You made the argument that they were processing every mouse packet. Everyone knew they were flagged bc everyones aryan told them they were. I made the argument they moved the flag variable from the client to the server. You then backed up your argumentt pointing to the mass aryan ban which was not due to your claim but a negative UID.

I don’t share your vision about their future anti-cheat methods.

Jagex usually stacks a bunch of anti-cheat stuff and releases them all at once, yearly, bi-yearly. They dont invent new ones every week. I believe the human cost prohibits jagex from going to the length blizzard has.

Read full topic

item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

zyle1992:

what it means, is before you deobbed the client, they all had class names like aa, ab, and wx.class. well, if you unjar the runescape.jar, they will all have those names. so the r.a, or dc Z, are just declarations, just like Class91.anInt1274. it’s exactly the same thing. as for the )2, and )3, those are just characters. )2 = -, )3 =., etc.

You don’t have the slightest idea of what the big boys are talking about do you?
And no, I don’t consider myself to be a big boy myself by any means.

As for FUD, good point frank_.

item.title: 498 - Strange Strings
item.dc:creator: @Krichevskoy Krichevskoy
item.description:
@Krichevskoy wrote:

Fair enough - I remembered Warden vaguely as some kind of modular execution framework, but, to be honest, have never looked into it or even played a game that uses it. I last heard of it during what must have been the initial fear reaction to a new anti-cheat move by Blizzard. In retrospect, I suppose it would have been bigger news if Warden had been as bad as all that for cheating.

@semaphore: I remember you mentioned quite a while ago that you thought they were building a custom VM, based on their reimplementation of Java system classes. I’ll admit frankly that I don’t know what a VM looks like - would you perhaps enlighten me as to what the markers are? I wouldn’t even know where to begin unraveling this.

edit: Alright, Greeny, you got me. You’re off the hook

Read full topic

item.title: 498 - Strange Strings
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Krichevskoy:

So Jagex can do modular and fairly opaque execution of arbitrary code now, or am I misremembering warden?

Warden dosen’t allow “modular and fairly opaque execution of arbitrary code”, or at least, not anymoreso than running a client you don’t have any knowledge of does (I mean the average user here)

Truth be told, I’m not sure where sema’s comparison of the RS client-side script VM (which I know next to nothing about, I might add) and warden are coming from. Wardens modularity/“scripting”/dynamicness is practically non existant, it’s pretty much a standard anticheat system that happens to apply a little polymorphic uh… theory to itself.

Words are basically failing me atm Sema, would it be possible for you to explain yourself at least one more level deep, even if you don’t want to give out tons of info? <3

Read full topic

item.title: 498 - Strange Strings
item.dc:creator: @ruler ruler
item.description:
@ruler wrote:

[quote=“ruler, post:20, topic:116887”][quote author=semaphore link=topic=166195.msg1549390#msg1549390 date=1182974873]

its was an interface update, only thing that should have broke are interface things, some menu’s, interface cache and array and things like that… was going to write some iface transforms today, but i forgot to download the newest client be4 the car ride (vacation)… and there wasn’t any wireless neer by… also… the wireless in this hotel sucks… gotta use a business comp… stuck with vista again =’(

Theoretical coders… instead of throwing stabs in the dark try actually looking at the code.

This update is the largest codebase changes since the massive rewrite in May of last year. They have changed some important portions of the game. Anyone that says otherwise either

[ul][li]Doesn’t understand the code[/li]
[li]Hasn’t looked at the code[/li]
[li]Is trying to make themselves look smart by patronizing those that have looked at the code[/li][/ul]

Bottom line is much has changed. Even maggots like ruler could see that the changes were significant.

[i]Seriously ruler? You seriously are naive enough to think I work for them? Wow... dumber than I thought... which in and of itself is an amazing feat...[/i]

@Silver Lining: The interface hooks they are talking about are the global ids that represent the current ‘in-focus’ interface ids. i.e. system instruction, npc instruction, full screen, etc.
[/quote]
“largest codebase changes since” - more like the only

" amazing feat" - you love to put jagex on a pedestal

I knew a engine update was coming. We were due for one. However i thought it would be on a much grander scale. If anything this will increase cheating, makes jagex look slow/weak.

semaphore, when will you stop building up jagex and stop tearing down cheaters.[/quote]

You have a history of doing this dating many years back. Like when you said they were watching every mouse packet of every client in the kaitnieks CM.

“They can do just about anything with that VM”.
"becomes many factors of 10 more difficult to unravel it "
I would call this FUD.

item.title: 498 - Strange Strings
item.dc:creator: @ruler ruler
item.description:
@ruler wrote:

[quote=“semaphore, post:6, topic:206697”]The scripting has been going on for quite some time. Searching for “slow” would bring you to the VM method that handles their custom scripting code. They have a fairly robust VM available to them. When I say VM I mean a customized virtual machine. I do not mean the java vm. I mean they have simulated a vm inside the game. This VM handles many tasks within the game. If you remember back around the time when the large array holding the interface cache was changed into a multidimensional array instead of one large single dimensional array, that is around when their custom VM was first implemented. (Don’t quote me on that… I’m saying it is around the time. I am not saying it is the exact build number…) It was also one of the ways they vastly improved performance/memory footprint of the game.

Whether this has to do with the messages you are seeing, I don’t know. I would imagine it does.

As a simple point of fact, they are stored somewhere Unhandled. They are stored in the cache. They store the scripts in bytecode format. Of course the bytecode is their own VM bytecode. I have to say I was impressed with their VM. They can do just about anything with that VM. And once they decide to make the opcodes dynamic, it becomes many factors of 10 more difficult to unravel it from build to build.

shangtsung1: if you would, please shut the hell up unless you have something to add which would imply that you actually know what a client is let alone what this client, in particular, does.[/quote]
fud

Read full topic
